div.p: From William Potter to George Turner
E97/3566, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.
The Hon. Sir George Turner M.P.,

Nothing but the pressure of such letters as the enclosed
The enclosed letter was from A. A. Sleight & Co. who were 'exceedingly disappointed that no attempt has yet been made to pay the funeral expenses of the late Baron'. In W. Potter to C. Topp, 27 March 1897, the amount cited for 'burial charges' is £35.5.6. (which came last night) would induce me to again trespass upon your attention at a time when you must be beset with important work connected with the approaching Federal Convention meeting and your intended visit to England.

If you could spare a moment for a consideration of the late Baron's case, his Executors would be deeply grateful. As it is six months since the Baron died the creditors say we have had ample time to appeal to the other Colonies for help. But I have pointed out that we cannot even do that until after we have received your decision upon the case.
MS annotation, 17 March 1897: 'Cabinet has decided to grant 9 months pay as gratuity to be paid to Executors at once — [Govt] will if requested by Memorial Committee contrib[ute] towards expense of monument to a reasonable amount'. R. Rogers, Secretary to the Premier, sent a letter to this effect to Potter on the same day and also forwarded the information to the Under Secretary, C. Topp.
Potter submitted a calculation of the amount M was entitled to from the Government in a note dated 15 March 1897:
'[…] for the Hon. the Premier.

Apologizing for thus troubling, and with congratulations on the grand success of yourself and your honoured Colleagues at the Federal election,
